title: Raiders’ Aldon Smith ordered to pay over $340,000 to 49ers within 10 days | Raiders Wire
text:
By: Will Reeve Jr. | 17 hours ago Follow @WillReevejr 
Oakland Raiders defensive end Aldon Smith’s NFL career continues to hang in limbo at the behest of NFL commissioner Roger Goodell. Meanwhile, the legal system has once again come calling for the 27-year old Monday. 
The San Francisco 49ers paid Smith approximately $8.9 million just before the edge rusher was met with a nine-game suspension on Aug. 27, 2016 for violating the league’s substance abuse policy. 49ers sue banished Raiders edge rusher Aldon Smith repayment of forfeited signing bonus https://t.co/p4if9DIiuw pic.twitter.com/IPRxCzHtsa 
— Scott Bair (@BairCSN) January 31, 2017 
The disciplinary action means Smith has to pay back over $1.1 million. According to court records, Smith has paid back just over $800,000 of that total. Related: PODCAST: Patriots, Falcons Wire Editors, Will Reeve Jr. discuss, predict Super Bowl 
In the court’s full decision it becomes clear what and why the court decided to do in order to get Smith to comply. 
“On Nov. 4, 2016, the system arbitrator issued an order (“Order”) requiring Smith to re-pay to the Forty Niners the balance of $341,630.18 within thirty days of the order.” Related: Goldman Sachs 're-evaluating' Raiders' Vegas relocation, move in 'jeopardy' 
When Smith didn’t comply with the initial 30-day order, the court modified the order to 10 days from Jan. 30, 2017 requiring his full repayment. The 27-year-old has been often troubled Smith in his young adult life. 
The complaint served as confirmation that the 10 days Smith originally had to appeal were now depleted. The 49ers now are seeking, and have been granted by the court, recuperation not only via cash, but also in attorney’s fees. Which is actually quite common in civil suits. Related: PODCAST: Patriots, Falcons Wire Editors, Will Reeve Jr. discuss, predict Super Bowl 
Smith has been trying to earn his way back into the good graces of the NFL for over one year. And this certainly won’t help his case. 
Whether or Smith has the cash to pony up right now, it only seems wise that he meets and speaks with those he needs to ASAP in order to avoid any sort of more impactful life derailment. 
As for when Oakland will get to see Smith back on the field? That’s an answer that has proven more elusive than Floyd Mayweather in an invisible man suit.
